Scientists in the Community Staff

Chanelle Case Borden, Ph.D. is a Program Analyst in the Center for Cancer Training (CCT). She received her Ph.D. in Molecular Oncology from George Washington University in 2012, in partnership with the National Institutes of Health Graduate Partnership Program (GPP).  Chanelle went on to complete a postdoctoral fellowship in the NCI where she investigated the biological function of BRD4 enzymatic activity in vivo and in vitro.  She joined the Center for Cancer Training in 2016 to pursue her passions in science education and increasing diversity in biomedical sciences.  Chanelle is currently the Program Manager of NCI Scientists in the Community, which began in 2017.

Past Team Members

Patricia A. Wiley, Ph.D. (former Assistant Program Manager) is currently a AAAS Fellow in the National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering (NIBIB). 

Cora Hersh (former Volunteer Coordinator) is currently a Research Assistant at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution.

El NCI se ha empeñado en aprovechar su papel como dirigente del Programa Nacional del Cáncer para extender nuestro entendimiento del cáncer y para traducir los nuevos conocimientos en una mejor prevención y un mejor tratamiento. Aunque la mayor parte del financiamiento del NCI respalda la ciencia iniciada por investigadores, el instituto invierte también en iniciativas principales de investigación para facilitar y apoyar la investigación de cuestiones específicas de importancia para la empresa de investigación del cáncer. Algunas de estas iniciativas clave son:

The National Cancer Institute's Office of Acquisitions (OA) negotiates, awards, and administers contracts and simplified acquisitions in support of NCI’s mission to prevent, diagnose, and treat cancer. OA conducts acquisitions for research and development services, non-research and development services, and supplies.

In Fiscal Year 2018, OA made over 450 contract awards, with a total potential contract value of over $1.85 billion.

Acquisition.gov
Acquisition.gov is the electronic source for the Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR).

HHS Acquisition Regulation (HHSAR)
The HHS Acquisition Regulation sets forth the Department of Health and Human Services’ own regulations, which supplement the federal-wide acquisition regulations.

System for Award Management
An organization must be registered in the System for Award Management (SAM) to receive most types of federal awards.

NIH electronic Contract Proposal Submission System (eCPS)
NIH eCPS is the electronic portal used for submitting most proposal or quotes in response to solicitations posted by the NIH on FedBizOpps.

NIH Contracts vs. Grants
This NIH resource page explains some of the differences between a contract and a grant funding mechanism.

NIH General Clause Listing
The NIH Office of Acquisition Management Policy website provides lists of general contract clauses that are expected to go into every NIH contract, depending on contract type.

NIH Acquisition Offices
There are ten acquisition offices supporting the National Institutes of Health.

NIH Human Subjects Research
NIH requirements for work performed under NIH contracts or grants that involves Human Subjects.

NIH Animal Welfare
NIH requirements for work performed under NIH contracts or grants that involves vertebrate animals.

HHS Small Business Program
The HHS Office of Small and Disadvantaged Business Utilization (OSDBU) helps small businesses in their pursuit of health and human services-related contracts.

Small Business Administration
The U.S. Small Business Administration provides assistance to small businesses looking for federal contracting opportunities.

The Patient-Derived Models Consortium (PDMC) is developing and characterizing patient-derived models to investigate the biological mechanisms that drive cancer phenotype and response to perturbations. Researchers of the PDMC design experiments that test and compare distinct patient-derived model approaches developed from common patient samples. This work aims to improve our understanding of the strengths and limitations of different patient-derived models as representations of human tumors. Additionally, systematic studies of patient-derived model parameters related to intrinsic tumor factors and microenvironmental pressures are being used to explore fundamental cancer biology research questions. The goal of the PDMC is to improve patient-derived models for basic cancer research that may inform the development of novel cancer therapies.   

The multidisciplinary teams working together across the PDMC include researchers with expertise in sample procurement, patient-derived models, cancer biology, and computational science. Additionally, the PDMC has a unique framework for sharing data and best practices to accelerate and standardize efforts related to the use of patient-derived models across the cancer research community.

Funding Opportunities

The Patient-Derived Models of Cancer Consortium (PDMC) consists of specialized U01 research projects. Information about the funding opportunity announcement for this consortium can be found at PAR-16-344: Biological Comparisons in Patient-Derived Models of Cancer.

The PDMC is comprised of the following U01 projects awarded through PAR-16-344:
